awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CDS&E: A framework for solution of coupled partial differential equations on heterogeneous parallel systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is aimed toward the development of a transformative software framework to more easily calculate complex mathematical models for science and engineering research. There is currently significant burden on scientists who need to execute their mathematical models on different supercomputers; code developed for one supercomputer must often be re-developing or significantly adjusted to run on other supercomputers. Streamlining this development process will make modern hardware including supercomputers more accessible and impactful for scientific computations. Beyond the benefits to the computational science research agenda of this project, the new software infrastructure is expected to similarly help other domain scientists who develop similar types of mathematical models. All developed software will be publicly released with an open-source license.

Our goal is to develop a framework for code generation and efficient parallel solution of a large coupled set of partial differential equations (PDEs) with minimal user intervention. The Finite Volume Method will be used for discretization of the PDEs on unstructured meshes.  From user-specified PDEs and their boundary and initial conditions in symbolic form, and characteristics of the target hardware platform, the framework will perform efficient code generation and enable load-balanced parallel execution. The generated parallel code can either be compiled and used as is, or can be used as a starting point for the insertion of additional physical models and features by advanced users. The software will be demonstrated for two problem types: (1) computation of reacting flows, in which multiple space and time dependent PDEs are non-linearly coupled, and (2) solution of the Boltzmann Transport Equation (BTE) for phonons, in which the discretization of the 7-dimensional BTE results in thousands of space and time dependent coupled PDEs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this research project was to develop a framework and domain-specific language (DSL) to automatically generate highly scalable and performant code for massively coupled PDE systems (>1000 PDEs) from a high-level description of the problem. The proposed code was to be demonstrated for solution of the Boltzmann Transport Equation (BTE) for phonons, which requires solution of approximately 16,000 PDEs.

While the University of Utah (Utah) team was responsible for the development of the DSL and the heterogeneous parallel code for solution of coupled PDEs, the Ohio State University (OSU) team was responsible for guiding the design of the code, and finally testing the code for the phonon BTE computation.

Notable technical accomplishments of the project include (1) development of a Julia-based DSL capable of both explicit and implicit solution of the phonon BTE from a high-level description, (2) development and demonstration of an adaptive parallel-solver that employs both CPUs and GPUs for solution of the phonon BTE that exhibited excellent strong scalability for up to 25,600 cores (3) demonstration and validation of the phonon BTE solver for the simulation of a Frequency Domain Thermo-Reflectance (FDTR) experiment as well as a Time Domain Thermo-Reflectance (TDTR) experiment—computations that represent the first of their kind, and has been deemed by this microscale thermal transport community as a major challenge.

The project resulted in 3 PhD dissertations, 1 book chapter, 4 journal publications, and 7 peer-reviewed conference publications thus far. 1 journal publication is in review. Several podium presentations were also delivered. Four graduate students (1 in Mechanical Engineering and 3 in Computer Science) were trained as part of this project. Two of these students now hold positions as faculty member in academia. Codes were disseminated through GitHub (https://github.com/paralab/parBTE).
